The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club gave a small "Dutch treat"
at the Johns Hopkins Club on
Monday, May 10. All the members of the club were there, and
ten or twelve others who will participate in the small plays written by Mitchell Carroll and Oscar
McCleary, and who are extremely
interested in the promotion of the
club's activities. 1)r. J. C. French
was the guest of honor. Charles
Leber, as president and spokesman, called on each of the seniors
to give a few words on their experiences in the years they were
connected with the club.
The election of officers came
next. A new office, that of "production manager," was created to
relieve the business manager of
some of his numerous duties. The
duties of the new officer are to
supervise all properties, scenery
and costumes and to be stage
manager,- leaving the business
manager to attend to the money
and general arrangements. The
new officers, who were elected
unanimously, are: Bartus Trew,
'21, president; Edward Norris,
'21, secretary; Holmes Boyd, '21,
business manager; Frank Smith,
Jr., '21, production manager. It
is the custom to elect an honorary
member . each year, and Dr.
French, because of hi$ interest in
Dramatic Club and undergraduate affairs in general, was elected
to this office.
Bartus Trew, the new president,
then took charge of the meeting,
which formed- a -decision on the
matter of financing the club to
relieve it of its debts and start it
off again next season. Each member pledged a sufficient sum, to be
paid baa next season, to clear
all expenses of "The Admirable
Crichton" and leave a surplus for
beginning in the fall.
It was definitely decided to
have a "Flay Night" on Thursday,
May 20, at which the two short
plays, "Burning • the Midnight
Oil," by Mitchell Carroll, and
"Mosaics," by Oscar—M-alleary,
will be presented. A stage is being
erected in the upper floor of the
Barn, with curtains and footlights. The affair is to be informal and primarily for the friends
of the actors and those interested
in promoting dramatics at Hopkins. No admission is to be
charged, but invitations to special
men are being given by Harry
Morriss and Edward Norris. Anyone who wishes to come can make

WORLDS

The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society recently held two very successful meetings. • The first of
these W:18 a smoker,- held in the
vestry rooms of the Madison Avenue Temple. The speaker was
Dr. Aaron Schaffer, who has re- •
cently returned from a tour of
France, Belgium and Italy. Dr.
Schaffer gave an interesting description of life among the JewA
of those countries.
He was
pleased to observe the feeling of
comradeship which he found existel between Jews from different
parts of the world. In France,
Judaism is not so widespread as
it is here, but it is on a more
systematic basis. For example,
the French rabbis are ma int a ined
by the state just as the priests
are. Zionism predominates in
France, but it also is not so widespread as it is in America, mainly for the reason that the problem of actual subsistence is so
much more acute in France. Dr.
Schaffer was complimented on the
e-:cellence • of his talk, and. the
(.11:11.111 with which it was deliv( I el, by the fifty or more—lewish
st ndents and alumni present.
The second meeting, which 'took
place at the University on May 5,
was addressed by Mr. Moses Baroway (A. B., 1.91.5). It was in the
nature of a. celebration. of the ,re,
cent decision of the League of
Nations Coniicil awarding a mandate.over Palestine to Great Britain: It was fitting that the
speaker should devote himself • to
a discussion of the. problems and
possibilities of Palestine. Mr.
Baroway, who spent a year in.
Palestine, described life in Jerusalem and in the Jewish agricultural colonies. He presented the
needs of the land, particularly in
the way of trained engineers and
scientific men. After his talk,
there was a long informal discussion of the various aspects
brought out in Mr. Baroway's
talk. The meeting was one of the
most interesting of the year.
The Zionist Society will hold
its final business -meeting in the
latter part of May. Election of
officers for the coming year will
be held.

Dr. Blank, who formerly had
charge of one on the chemical departments, has resigned his position here and also with the State
Food and Drug Commission,
which he held at the same time,
to accept a position with the
American Cannery Company. He
will be in charge of a district
composed of Maryland and Delaware, and will have his headquarters in Easton, Md.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAY 18, 1920

A non athletic fee is something
which is mucli needed at Hopkins.
A word of explanation of the proposed plan might here be in order.
It is a scheme by which money
for the support of all non-athletic
activities is collected in a lump
sum at the beginning of the year,
as is the athletic fee. The fee, as
proposed, is $10, divided approximately as follows: Hullabaloo,
$3.25; Dramatic Club, $2 (one
orchestra seat); NEws - LETTER,
$2.50 (for if present plans carry
through, THE NEWS-LETTER will
be a semi-weekly next year); Musical Clubs, debating and bulletin,
each 50 cents. This totals $9.25,
the remaining 75 cents is to be
kept as a reserve fund to foster
the development of new activities.
There is a crying need for just
such a system. It will reach the
very people whom everyone interested in the welfare of Hopkins
has been vainly striving to reach,
the slackers who do not have
enough college spirit to take a
little interest in the University.
It will not affect the student who
is interested in college activities,
for he will have spent as much, if
not. more, during his college year
on these activities; but the

NON-ATHLETIC FEE SUGGESTED
Tentative Petition Drawn Up —Criticism
and Alterations Invited -Petition to
Be Presented at Mass-meeting.

_The following tentative petition
has been drawn up to be presented at a student mass-meeting on
Thursday, May 27. It provides
for a non-athletic fee to be levied
in the same manner as the present
athletic fee, and provides for a
central control of all of the nonathletic activities, at the same
time taking away from these activities none of their rightful
powers. Such a plan has been
worked with great success at
many other institutions.
The plan is purely tentative,
and it is hoped that it will call
forth a great deal of discussion
between 110W and the mass-meeting. All who are interested and
desire to suggest alterations or
additions to the proposal are
urged to do so. As many such
suggestions as possible, providing
they are placed in THE NEWSLETTER box before 12 o'clock Saturday, will be published in next
week's issue. In the same issue
the petition as altered will be
published.
If passed by the student body
at the mass-meeting, the revised
petition will be presented to the
Trustees, with a request urging
them to take action on it as soon
as possible. The petition in its
tentative form is as follows:
"Resolved, that we, the student
body of Johns Hopkins University, request the Board of Trustees to establish a fee of .$10 to be
devoted to non-athletic activities,
which fee is to be paid by each
student upon entrance to the University, as is the present athletic
fee.
"That this fee shall be turned
over to the 'Varsity Seal Voting
Council, to be divided among the
different non-athletic activities as
it sees fit, subject to. the approval
of the chairman of the Student
Affairs Committee.
"That a uniform system of accounts for all non-athletic activities be adopted under the supervision of the 'Varsity Seal Voting
Council, and that these accounts
be open at all times to inspection
by the chairman of the Student
Affairs Committee and such committees as the faculty or student
body see fit to appoint.
"The advantages of such a system* are as follows:
-1. It insures to non-athletic
activities the support which they
have failed to receive in the past.
"2. It thus enable, them to
cover a greater field than before.
"3. It places the burden of
support equally on all students.
"4. It thus arouses interest
throughout the entire student
body.
"5. It saves the non-athletic
activities hundreds of dollars and

FRESHMAN LACROSSE

7

FACULTY NOTES

Penn has been invited to run in
England next year, according to
an announcement recently made.
Col. A. N. S. Jackson, the manager of this year's English team
and star .of the English entries
in 1914, stated concerning this.
"My plan is to invite the Red and
Blue to send a relay team to Oxford University and have Cambridge take part in the same meet,
thus making it a triangular affair."
A conference on the question of
the distance which will be run and'
other problems regarding the same
meet will be held before the Englishmen return to England. Before going back, the team will
visit Cornell and then will go to
Yale and Harvard. It is rumored
that while in New Haven, Colonel
Jackson will try to arrange for a •
visit to England by a combined
Harvard and Yale team some time
this summer.
Dattntount has already closed
its rolls to the incoming Freshman Class. More than 1,000 applications have been received and
of these less than 600 can be accepted. Lad: of housing facilities prevents the New Hampshire
college from allowing more than
550 new men to enter this fall, alt.“,ugh the registration ottice estimates that 2,000 new students desire admission. Next .year's enrollment is placed at approximately 1,900.
Prof. Harry Woodburn Chase,
Dartmouth, '04, has recently been
inaugurated president of the University of North Carolina, the ol(1est State university in the United
States. President Chase received
his A. B. and M. A. degrees at
Dartmouth, and his Ph. 1). several
years later from Clark University.
He has been professor at North
Carolina since 1909, where he has
specialized in psychology.
The Yale Union, which was
founded last lea' as a means of
stimulating university interest in
public affairs of every kind and
to form a unified organization to
precipitate undergraduate opinion
in these matters, will continue as
a regular university feature in the
future.
A committee has been appointed from the Junior Class to carry
on the activities started by the
founders, who will be at Oxford
next year. It is thus planned to
exchange views between the Oxford and Yale Unions on all mutual problems, and it is further
planned to hold a number of meetings at which men well known in
political life will speak.

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club gave a small "Dutch treat"
at the Johns Hopkins Club on
Monday, May 10. All the members of the club were there, and
ten or twelve others who will participate in the small plays written by Mitchell Carroll and Oscar
McCleary, and who are extremely
interested in the promotion of the
club's activities. 1)r. J. C. French
was the guest of honor. Charles
Leber, as president and spokesman, called on each of the seniors
to give a few words on their experiences in the years they were
connected with the club.
The election of officers came
next. A new office, that of "production manager," was created to
relieve the business manager of
some of his numerous duties. The
duties of the new officer are to
supervise all properties, scenery
and costumes and to be stage
manager,- leaving the business
manager to attend to the money
and general arrangements. The
new officers, who were elected
unanimously, are: Bartus Trew,
'21, president; Edward Norris,
'21, secretary; Holmes Boyd, '21,
business manager; Frank Smith,
Jr., '21, production manager. It
is the custom to elect an honorary
member . each year, and Dr.
French, because of hi$ interest in
Dramatic Club and undergraduate affairs in general, was elected
to this office.
Bartus Trew, the new president,
then took charge of the meeting,
which formed- a -decision on the
matter of financing the club to
relieve it of its debts and start it
off again next season. Each member pledged a sufficient sum, to be
paid baa next season, to clear
all expenses of "The Admirable
Crichton" and leave a surplus for
beginning in the fall.
It was definitely decided to
have a "Flay Night" on Thursday,
May 20, at which the two short
plays, "Burning • the Midnight
Oil," by Mitchell Carroll, and
"Mosaics," by Oscar—M-alleary,
will be presented. A stage is being
erected in the upper floor of the
Barn, with curtains and footlights. The affair is to be informal and primarily for the friends
of the actors and those interested
in promoting dramatics at Hopkins. No admission is to be
charged, but invitations to special
men are being given by Harry
Morriss and Edward Norris. Anyone who wishes to come can make

WORLDS

The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society recently held two very successful meetings. • The first of
these W:18 a smoker,- held in the
vestry rooms of the Madison Avenue Temple. The speaker was
Dr. Aaron Schaffer, who has re- •
cently returned from a tour of
France, Belgium and Italy. Dr.
Schaffer gave an interesting description of life among the JewA
of those countries.
He was
pleased to observe the feeling of
comradeship which he found existel between Jews from different
parts of the world. In France,
Judaism is not so widespread as
it is here, but it is on a more
systematic basis. For example,
the French rabbis are ma int a ined
by the state just as the priests
are. Zionism predominates in
France, but it also is not so widespread as it is in America, mainly for the reason that the problem of actual subsistence is so
much more acute in France. Dr.
Schaffer was complimented on the
e-:cellence • of his talk, and. the
(.11:11.111 with which it was deliv( I el, by the fifty or more—lewish
st ndents and alumni present.
The second meeting, which 'took
place at the University on May 5,
was addressed by Mr. Moses Baroway (A. B., 1.91.5). It was in the
nature of a. celebration. of the ,re,
cent decision of the League of
Nations Coniicil awarding a mandate.over Palestine to Great Britain: It was fitting that the
speaker should devote himself • to
a discussion of the. problems and
possibilities of Palestine. Mr.
Baroway, who spent a year in.
Palestine, described life in Jerusalem and in the Jewish agricultural colonies. He presented the
needs of the land, particularly in
the way of trained engineers and
scientific men. After his talk,
there was a long informal discussion of the various aspects
brought out in Mr. Baroway's
talk. The meeting was one of the
most interesting of the year.
The Zionist Society will hold
its final business -meeting in the
latter part of May. Election of
officers for the coming year will
be held.

Dr. Blank, who formerly had
charge of one on the chemical departments, has resigned his position here and also with the State
Food and Drug Commission,
which he held at the same time,
to accept a position with the
American Cannery Company. He
will be in charge of a district
composed of Maryland and Delaware, and will have his headquarters in Easton, Md.

A non athletic fee is something
which is mucli needed at Hopkins.
A word of explanation of the proposed plan might here be in order.
It is a scheme by which money
for the support of all non-athletic
activities is collected in a lump
sum at the beginning of the year,
as is the athletic fee. The fee, as
proposed, is $10, divided approximately as follows: Hullabaloo,
$3.25; Dramatic Club, $2 (one
orchestra seat); NEws - LETTER,
$2.50 (for if present plans carry
through, THE NEWS-LETTER will
be a semi-weekly next year); Musical Clubs, debating and bulletin,
each 50 cents. This totals $9.25,
the remaining 75 cents is to be
kept as a reserve fund to foster
the development of new activities.
There is a crying need for just
such a system. It will reach the
very people whom everyone interested in the welfare of Hopkins
has been vainly striving to reach,
the slackers who do not have
enough college spirit to take a
little interest in the University.
It will not affect the student who
is interested in college activities,
for he will have spent as much, if
not. more, during his college year
on these activities; but the

NON-ATHLETIC FEE SUGGESTED
Tentative Petition Drawn Up —Criticism
and Alterations Invited -Petition to
Be Presented at Mass-meeting.

_The following tentative petition
has been drawn up to be presented at a student mass-meeting on
Thursday, May 27. It provides
for a non-athletic fee to be levied
in the same manner as the present
athletic fee, and provides for a
central control of all of the nonathletic activities, at the same
time taking away from these activities none of their rightful
powers. Such a plan has been
worked with great success at
many other institutions.
The plan is purely tentative,
and it is hoped that it will call
forth a great deal of discussion
between 110W and the mass-meeting. All who are interested and
desire to suggest alterations or
additions to the proposal are
urged to do so. As many such
suggestions as possible, providing
they are placed in THE NEWSLETTER box before 12 o'clock Saturday, will be published in next
week's issue. In the same issue
the petition as altered will be
published.
If passed by the student body
at the mass-meeting, the revised
petition will be presented to the
Trustees, with a request urging
them to take action on it as soon
as possible. The petition in its
tentative form is as follows:
"Resolved, that we, the student
body of Johns Hopkins University, request the Board of Trustees to establish a fee of .$10 to be
devoted to non-athletic activities,
which fee is to be paid by each
student upon entrance to the University, as is the present athletic
fee.
"That this fee shall be turned
over to the 'Varsity Seal Voting
Council, to be divided among the
different non-athletic activities as
it sees fit, subject to. the approval
of the chairman of the Student
Affairs Committee.
"That a uniform system of accounts for all non-athletic activities be adopted under the supervision of the 'Varsity Seal Voting
Council, and that these accounts
be open at all times to inspection
by the chairman of the Student
Affairs Committee and such committees as the faculty or student
body see fit to appoint.
"The advantages of such a system* are as follows:
-1. It insures to non-athletic
activities the support which they
have failed to receive in the past.
"2. It thus enable, them to
cover a greater field than before.
"3. It places the burden of
support equally on all students.
"4. It thus arouses interest
throughout the entire student
body.
"5. It saves the non-athletic
activities hundreds of dollars and

AT OTHER COLLEGES

FRESHMAN LACROSSE

7

FACULTY NOTES

Penn has been invited to run in
England next year, according to
an announcement recently made.
Col. A. N. S. Jackson, the manager of this year's English team
and star .of the English entries
in 1914, stated concerning this.
"My plan is to invite the Red and
Blue to send a relay team to Oxford University and have Cambridge take part in the same meet,
thus making it a triangular affair."
A conference on the question of
the distance which will be run and'
other problems regarding the same
meet will be held before the Englishmen return to England. Before going back, the team will
visit Cornell and then will go to
Yale and Harvard. It is rumored
that while in New Haven, Colonel
Jackson will try to arrange for a •
visit to England by a combined
Harvard and Yale team some time
this summer.
Dattntount has already closed
its rolls to the incoming Freshman Class. More than 1,000 applications have been received and
of these less than 600 can be accepted. Lad: of housing facilities prevents the New Hampshire
college from allowing more than
550 new men to enter this fall, alt.“,ugh the registration ottice estimates that 2,000 new students desire admission. Next .year's enrollment is placed at approximately 1,900.
Prof. Harry Woodburn Chase,
Dartmouth, '04, has recently been
inaugurated president of the University of North Carolina, the ol(1est State university in the United
States. President Chase received
his A. B. and M. A. degrees at
Dartmouth, and his Ph. 1). several
years later from Clark University.
He has been professor at North
Carolina since 1909, where he has
specialized in psychology.
The Yale Union, which was
founded last lea' as a means of
stimulating university interest in
public affairs of every kind and
to form a unified organization to
precipitate undergraduate opinion
in these matters, will continue as
a regular university feature in the
future.
A committee has been appointed from the Junior Class to carry
on the activities started by the
founders, who will be at Oxford
next year. It is thus planned to
exchange views between the Oxford and Yale Unions on all mutual problems, and it is further
planned to hold a number of meetings at which men well known in
political life will speak.
